   An overall system to manage the development and implementation of a risk management program.



A description of the regulated substances handled: The Mill Creek Station is an electric power generation station.  Anhydrous ammonia is the only CAA 112(r) RMP regulated substance, at this facility, above the threshold quantity levels established by EPA. 



Anhydrous ammonia, stored in two 60,000 gallon storage tanks, is contained in the SCR system, which is delivered to the stack to reduce nitrous oxides emissions. Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a colorless gas at ambient temperature or pressure; it is, however, stored as a liquid under pressure.  The gas is less dense than air, but when liquid anhydrous ammonia is released it may aerosolize and behave as a dense gas.  The effects of anhydrous ammonia inhalation range from irritation to severe respiratory injuries to death.  Anhydrous ammonia is self-alarming; its strong odor is noticeable at concentrations above 50 ppm; the concentration that is immediately dangerous to life and health (IDLH) is 300 ppm.  In general, people will not remain in the presence of anhydrous ammonia so that the primary threat is to people who are unable to evacuate the area.



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:  This facility complies with requirements for hazardous materials use, and it is Mill Creek Station?s policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If an emergency were to occur, it is Mill Creek Station?s policy to notify 911, the Jefferson County LEPC, and respond to the emergency.  A site specific emergency plan has been developed to address emergencies.



Ten-year accident history:  The Mill Creek Station has not had an accident in the past ten years involving anhydrous ammonia.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:  This facility complies with EPA's accident p

revention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with applicable ANSI guidelines, engineering codes, manufacturer specifications, best management practices, and state law.  The Mill Creek Station is required to comply with the most stringent EPA RMP and OSHA prevention programs.



The emergency response program: In the event of an emergency involving the anhydrous ammonia system, the automated controls or the operator will close the main valves, shut down the system and evacuate the immediate area. When staffing levels permit, the in-house Response Team will take appropriate measures including the use of standard fire hoses to contain the release. Outside agencies are available to respond to releases beyond the capabilities, level of expertise or availability of the in-house emergency response team. If any release is likely to impact off site, the local emergency services will be notified. Mill Creek Station has an in-house response team whose members are trained to the Hazardous Materials Technician level as defined by 29 CFR 1910.120. Mill Creek Station employees are trained to use self-contained breathing equipment and have taken OSHA worker right-to-know training. Outside agencies are available to respond to releases beyond the capabilities or level of expertise of the in-house emergency response team.
